rows.text_1:
Spending One-on-One Time with your child 

Today we will look at spending One-on-One Time with your child.
Spending special time with your child will make them feel valued and loved.
It will also build trust and respect, and support them in learning new things.
rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Our children don’t need expensive gifts. The best gift we can give them is to spend one-on-one time with them.

By spending time together, you will understand your child better and they will learn many new things.

Having special time with your child will help them feel loved and valued. That will make everything easier at home!

rows.text_1:
One-on-One Time can be fun for you and your child.

Let’s look at how {F2_GRANDMOTHER} and {F2_DAUGHTER_3} do this!

rows.text_2:
*{F2_DAUGHTER_3} and {F2_GRANDMOTHER} are starting One-on-One Time.* 
 {F2_GRANDMOTHER} : “I have 5 minutes of One-on-One Time to spend with you, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}. What would you like to do?”
 {F2_DAUGHTER_3} : “I want to play dress-up!”
{F2_GRANDMOTHER} : “Wonderful idea, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}! I see you are taking out the yellow scarf with blue stripes on it.”

{F2_DAUGHTER_3} : “{F2_GRANDMOTHER}, it’s for you.”
 {F2_GRANDMOTHER} : “Thank you, I love it!”
 {F2_DAUGHTER_3} : “Wear it, {F2_GRANDMOTHER}!”

{F2_DAUGHTER_3} finds a dress to wear.
 {F2_GRANDMOTHER} : “Well done for getting dressed by yourself, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}. You are such a big girl!”

rows.text_1: Here are some easy tips on how to connect with your child:
rows.section_1_text: Spend 5 minutes (or more!) with your child each day.
rows.section_2_text: Switch off the TV, put aside phones, and remove distractions. Show your child that you are really paying attention.
rows.section_2_extra_text:
Look at your child. Get down to their level. Use their name.
Describe what they are doing and feeling. Praise them.
Your child will learn a lot from what you say and do.
rows.section_3_text:
Ask to spend time with your child. Let them choose what to do or talk about. 
Try different activities together. Have fun!
rows.section_3_extra_text: This will help your child feel important and valued.

Want to try it out? 

Spend 5 minutes (or more) of One-on-One Time with your child, every day.
rows.media_title: How it helped a parent like you:
rows.media_transcript:
When I first heard I have to spend One-on-One Time with my daughter, it was hard for me. I did not know when to do it or what to say. I did not want to spoil my daughter so that she thinks we have to do everything together. 
But I really wanted to build my relationship with her and I wanted her to open up about what was troubling her. 
So we tried the One-on-One Time. 
First, it felt weird, but it turned out to be fun! Now we play her favourite game together and talk about things happening at school and with her friends.
